clinical_study.brief_title: Decision-Making and the Relationship to Food Intake in Kids
clinical_study.official_title: Understanding Decision-Making and the Relationship to Food Intake in Children 7 to 11 Years Old

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this 18-month project is to investigate how decision-making influences food choice and consumption in children ages 7 to 11 years old. Although several studies suggest that the ability to make good decisions relates to eating behaviors, no studies have looked at how food reward influences the decision-making process to impact actual food intake. This proposal will answer these questions and bridge this gap in knowledge, which could lead to the development of more effective interventions for childhood obesity. To accomplish this, the investigators have assembled a diverse team with expertise in food intake, nutrition, and decision sciences. First, the investigators will establish if there are differences in decision-making between children varying in weight status. Second, the investigators will determine if performance on behavioral decision-making tasks relates to food consumption in the laboratory. Third, the investigators will examine response functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response to various rewards (i.e. food and money) and determine if this is influenced by child weight status. Fourth, the investigators will examine differences in fMRI BOLD at rest in decision-making regions are correlated with food intake and weight status. Eighty-two children will participate in our study. The long-term goal of this project is to investigate if there are differences in brain regions corresponding to these behaviors in overweight children and if these differences relate to eating behaviors in this population. Children will undergo fMRI while playing a reward task as well as consume meals in our laboratory. Decision-making will also be assessed by having children complete various behavioral measurements of reward and inhibitory control.

primary_outcome.measure: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response to various reward types (food, money, no reward).
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at fMRI scan at week 4
primary_outcome.description: Regions of interest BOLD analysis of an fMRI card-guessing task for various reward types

primary_outcome.measure: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response at rest (resting-state fMRI)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at fMRI scan at week 4
primary_outcome.description: Regions of interest BOLD analysis of resting-state fMRI to examine differences in brain regions of interest at rest
Measured by performance on a go/nogo task

primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected after the behavioral inhibitory control task (same visit), which is either week 1-3 (randomized)
primary_outcome.description: Measured by performance on a go/nogo task with a reward incentive
Measured by performance on the hungry donkey task
Measured by performance on a dietary self-control task

secondary_outcome.description: Measured at an objective laboratory test-meal (kcal and grams)

secondary_outcome.measure: Energy intake at a buffet meal
secondary_outcome.description: Measured at an objective laboratory test-meal (kcal and grams)

secondary_outcome.measure: Energy intake after a meal preload
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Collected at either week 1-3 (randomized) following the baseline meal
secondary_outcome.description: Measured at an objective laboratory test-meal (kcal and grams)

secondary_outcome.measure: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response to various reward types (food, money, no reward).
secondary_outcome.description: Whole brain BOLD analysis of an fMRI card-guessing task for various reward types

secondary_outcome.measure: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) response at baseline
secondary_outcome.description: Whole brain BOLD analysis of an fMRI card-guessing task for various reward types

other_outcome.time_frame: Collected after each meal at multiple time points during weeks 1-4
other_outcome.description: Ratings of how much the child likes each food in the meal on a visual analog scale

other_outcome.time_frame: Collected at multiple time points during weeks 1-4
other_outcome.description: Ratings of how full the child feels measured on a child-friendly visual analog scale
Child report of pubertal status questionnaire
Height in cm measured by stadiometer
Weight in kg measured by a standard digital scale
Assessed by bioelectrical impedance analysis scale
Calculated from height, age, sex
Calculated from height, weight, age and sex - according to the Center for Disease Control (CDC) standards
Calculated from height, weight, age and sex - according to CDC standards
Calculated from height, weight, age, sex
Calculated from height, weight, age, sex
Parent-reported questionnaire of habitual eating styles in children
Parent-reported questionnaire of feeding practices
Parent-report questionnaire

Loss of control when eating is frequently reported in middle childhood. Loss of control when eating was assessed via interview-style questionnaire to determine pre-clinical binge-like eating behaviors that may influence the primary outcome of energy intake at the 4 conditions of test-meals.

other_outcome.measure: Inhibitory control and reward sensitivity questionnaires
other_outcome.description: Parent and child report of inhibitory control and reward sensitivity on a questionnaire
Age of participant
sex of participant
height in cm of parent measured by a stadiometer
weight in kg of parent measured by a standard digital scale
measured by bioelectrical impedance
Parent report of pubertal status questionnaire

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Right-handed
- English as native language
- Reading at/above grade level
- Not Claustrophobic
- Generally Healthy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Left-handedness
- Metal in or on body that cannot be removed
- Claustrophobia
- Medication usage that may alter brain activity or blood flow
- Medical disorder that may impact comfort of safety in MRI scanner
- Food Allergies
- Dietary Restrictions
- Learning Disabilities
- Psychiatric Disorders

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor, Department of Nutritional Sciences and Food Science
